title: Nash-equilibria and N-fold integer programming
summary:
Inspired by a paper of R. W. Rosenthal, we investigate generalized
Nash-equilibria of integer programming games. We show that generalized
Nash-equilibria always exist and are related to an optimal solution of a
so-called N-fold integer program. This link allows us to establish some
polynomial time complexity results about solving this optimization problem and
its inverse counter-part.

Abstract
Inspired by a paper of R. W. Rosenthal, we investigate generalized Nash-equilibria of
integer programming games. We show that generalized Nash-equilibria always exist and are
related to an optimal solution of a so-called N -fold integer program. This link allows us to
establish some polynomial time complexity results about solving this optimization problem
and its inverse counter-part.


The following remark seems in order. Notice that the objective function in Problem(1) can be
interpreted as the costs of a provider to account for realizing all the strategies. The costs assigned
2

 to a player, however, are marginal costs. If all cj , j = 1, . . . , n, are nonlinear convex functions,
the sum of costs for all players exceeds the costs for the provider, i.e., it generates a gain for the
provider. The more players play the bigger this gain gets. This fact motivates the provider to have
all his players being satisfied. Interestingly, each player is satisfied when they cooperate to minimize
the costs of the provider.

3

Inverse optimization problem

A (generalized) Nash-equilibrium satisfies all players simultaneously. It requires that cost functions
cj , j = 1, . . . , n, are given. Conversely, one may ask for finding cost functions cj , j = 1, . . . , n, that
turn a given set {x1 , . . . , xN } of strategies into a Nash-equilibrium. Such inverse optimization
problems are fundamental for a variety of applications, such as quality control in production
systems, portfolio optimization, or production capacity planning, see [9] for details and references.
The problem in this generality is hopeless unless some structure on the cost functions cj , j =
1, . . . , n, can be assumed. We study the situation that each cj has the form cj (y) = λj fj (y) for
some fixed given convex function fj : R+ → R+ and some λj ∈ R+ that can be adjusted.
We can abstract from this setting slightly and define a general inverse integer optimization problem
as follows.
